balance.translation[0].definitions[0].de: a state in which all your weight is evenly spread so that you do not fall
balance.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: I lost my balance and fell on my face.
balance.translation[0].definitions[1].de: a state in which opposite forces or influences exist in equal or the correct amounts, in a way that is good
balance.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: Try to keep a balance between work and play.
Pesticides seriously upset the balance of nature.
balance.translation[0].definitions[2].de: the amount of money that you have in your bank account
balance.translation[0].definitions[3].de: the balance of a debt is the amount of money that you still owe after you have paid some of it
balance.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: The balance is due at the end of the month.
balance.translation[0].definitions[4].de: an instrument for weighing things, with two dishes that hang from a bar
balance.translation[0].definitions[5].de: when someone’s mind is healthy and their emotional state is normal
balance.translation[0].definitions[5].ex: The death of her friend had disturbed the balance of her mind.
balance.translation[0].note_box[0].headi: – Meaning 1: a state in which all your weight is evenly spread so that you do not fall
balance.translation[0].note_box[0].secti: The sea was so rough that it was hard to keep your balance.
She nearly lost her balance as the bus suddenly moved forward.
He held onto Carrie until he regained his balance.
The blow was hard enough to knock him off balance.
A good sense of balance is always useful when you are sailing.
balance.translation[0].note_box[1].headi: – Meaning 2: a state in which opposite forces or influences exist in equal or the correct amounts, in a way that is good
balance.translation[0].note_box[1].secti: strike/achieve/find a balance
It is necessary to strike a balance between the needs of employers and employees.
Find the right balance between enough exercise and enough rest.
keep/maintain a balance
Try to keep a balance between your spending and your earnings.
A firm must strive to maintain a balance between business and financial risk.
upset the balance
The move could upset the delicate balance of power in the Middle East.
change/alter/shift the balance
Will this alter the balance of power in the EU?
His appointment shifted the government’s balance decisively to the right.
redress the balance
What can be done to redress the balance in favour of women?
a good/healthy balance
You should eat a good balance of carbohydrates and protein.
Are you eating a healthy balance of foods?
a fine balance
Teachers need to strike a fine balance of flexibility and control.
a delicate balance
Too much carbon dioxide in the atmosphere upsets the delicate balance of gases.
the right/proper/correct balance
With sport, you have to find the right balance between competition and fun.
the natural balance
Chemicals will upset the natural balance of the pond.
the ecological balance
Human activity is ruining the ecological balance of our planet.
the political/military balance
By this time, the political balance in the Cabinet had altered.
the balance of power
the European balance of power
the balance of nature
Nothing can justify permanent damage to the balance of nature.
balance.translation[1].definitions[0].de: to be in or get into a steady position, without falling to one side or the other, or to put something into this position
balance.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: She was balancing a plate of food on her knees.
He turned around, balancing awkwardly on one foot.
balance.translation[1].definitions[1].de: to be equal in importance, amount, value, or effect to something that has the opposite effect
balance.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: Job losses in manufacturing were balanced by job increases in the service sector.
just enough sugar to balance the acidity of the fruit
balance.translation[1].definitions[2].de: to consider the importance of one thing in relation to something else when you are making a decision
balance.translation[1].definitions[2].ex: The courts must balance our liberty against the security of the nation.
balance.translation[2].definitions[0].de: the difference between the total amounts of money coming into and going out of an account in a particular period of time
balance.translation[2].definitions[1].de: an amount still owed after some money has been paid
balance.translation[2].definitions[1].ex: The firm has paid $128,000, but whether it will ever pay the balance remains uncertain.
Most people have an outstanding balance on their credit cards for a couple of months, then pay it off.
balance.translation[2].definitions[2].de: the rest or remaining part of an amount
balance.translation[2].definitions[2].ex: 20,000 barrels a day are shipped to San Francisco, and the balance is delivered by pipeline directly to Los Angeles.
balance.translation[3].definitions[0].de: to calculate the amount needed to make the debit side and the credit side of an account equal, perhaps by looking for mistakes
balance.translation[3].definitions[1].de: if the debit and credit sides of an account balance, they show the same amounts
balance.translation[3].definitions[2].de: to do what is necessary to spend no more than the amount of money received, usually by a government
balance.translation[3].definitions[2].ex: Costa Rica has worked on programs with the International Monetary Fund to balance its accounts.
Real differences exist between the administration and Congress over how to balance the budget and where to cut taxes.
